What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the foundations of neurobiology, from neuronal structure to seminal experiments in the field.
some basic ideas about Neurobiology. Drawing neural circuits is a fantastic and clear way to analyze the pathway of neural system

I learned the fundamental principles of neuronal signaling and the scientific experiments that led to these discoveries. I learned about the specific biological signaling pathways responsible for the function of different structures in the brain.

I learned a lot about various intricate neurobiological machinations and mechanisms that enable the human brain to carry out the complex functions that we rely on on a day to day basis. This includes topics ranging from the electrochemistry governing neuronal synapses and action potentials, to the nervous circuitry contributing to motor control and learning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Its a little quick and the material is unbalanced as far as how much is taught per week. Perhaps it might benefit from a little more top-down organization and structure.
The strengths of the class are the broad range of topics covered. It could be improved with more student interaction, as opposed to only lecturing.

One strength of this course is that the handouts were very well written and detailed and explained complex information that we learned in class. Another strength is that lectures were very engaging, and I enjoyed not only going over the discoveries, but also the logic behind different experiments. One weakness is that while I really appreciated the extra hour long discussion section, I think I would have benefited from it more if it wasn't right after our Monday lecture. This would have given me a bit more time to digest the information and formulate questions.

The strengths of the course are that the material is very interesting, and goes into fine detail about how exactly the biological processes work, and there is always something new to learn in every class. Additionally, Professor Keshishian's handouts are extremely helpful for understanding the difficult material. However, the exam structure of the course is not preferable, as the entire grade consists of only three exams, for which the class structure provides little to no dedicated resources. I believe that a great improvement would be to provide practice problems for both midterms as well as the final exam, rather than just the first midterm.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes for anyone declaring a Neuroscience Major this class has important basics.

This course is required for Neuroscience majors, so make sure to plan your schedule accordingly. It will require a lot of brain power and time, so try not to overload your schedule with credits. Go to office hours and reach out to peer tutors. Don't be afraid to ask for help!
yes!!

I would recommend this course, especially to students interested in biology, because it goes into much greater depth about specific signaling pathways than other neuroscience classes I have taken. Additionally, instead of using rote memorization, we drew connections because the mechanisms of each signaling pathway to make them more understandable.

I would recommend this class to neuroscience majors, as it is required and provides a lot of insight into neurobiological processes they may not have learned about previously. As for non-neuroscience majors, it depends on the level of interest and exposure to neurobiology concepts. The focus of this course operates at a deeper level of understanding. It may require significant effort to understand the material for those with only the most basic knowledge of the topics.

comments: Strongly Agree

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will use all that I have learned in this course in neurobiology lab next semester! I'm excited to have a foundation before entering the lab course.

I will take the experimental methods we learned about and think about how I could possibly apply them to research I do in the future. In future classes that are more behavior based, I will continue to think about the biological mechanisms and consider the reasons why a behavioral phenomena is occurring.
